newsitem.title: USA: Apple shares continue to rise on Microsoft deal.
newsitem.headline: Apple shares continue to rise on Microsoft deal.

text.p: Shares of Apple Computer Inc. continued to soar on Thursday, reaching the highest level in 18 months amid optimism that the $150 million investment from Microsoft Corp. and a new board of directors will bolster the fortunes of the computer maker.
Separately, a source close to Grupo Carso said the Mexican conglomerate bought a 3 percent stake in Apple for $60 million at $16 per share. The source declined to give a date for the transaction.

Apple closed at $29.19, up $2.875 or 10.8 percent on Nasdaq, where it was the most active stock with 33 million shares changing hands. Earlier, the stock hit a 52-week high of $29.75. In the past month, the stock has more than doubled from $13.
Apple's surge on Wall Street made the stock options some Apple employees receive as part of their compensation extremely valuable for now.

"I am doing great -- getting better. I'm selling all my Apple stock," said Dale Fuller, the former head of Apple's Powerbook division. "Whoohoo!" he shouted into his cellular phone as he drove down the freeway.
Options allow employees to buy their company's stock at a discount to the market price. Silicon Valley companies rely heavily on options to pay their employees.

In Apple's case, key employees were given stock options in July with an "exercise price" of $13.25 a share. One thousand of those options had a paper value of $16,500 Thursday as Apple stock hit $30 a share. Those same options were nearly worthless a month ago, when Apple's stock lingered at about $14.

There's one catch: Employees have to wait at least a year from this past July to cash the options in. Depending on various terms, they can only cash them in batches stretched over three to five years.
But Gilbert Amelio, the former Apple chairman who was ousted last month, may not have to wait as long to cash in on the company's revival.
Under his employment contract, Amelio received options on one million shares of Apple stock with an exercise price of $26.25 a share, making them worth nearly $2.94 million.
The options became vested after he left Apple.
On Wednesday Microsoft agreed to invest $150 million in one-time mortal enemy Apple, promised to continue to write business software for the Macintosh and agreed to share its technology with Apple.

Apple also revamped its board of directors. It named four computer industry heavyweights, including Oracle Corp. Chairman Larry Ellison, Intuit Inc. President Bill Campell, Apple co-founder Steve Jobs and former International Business Machines Corp. finance chief Jerome York.

"Can you think of better news? This is very good for Apple," said Daniel Kunstler, analyst at JP Morgan Securities in San Francisco. Kunstler Thursday lifted Apple's stock rating to "long-term buy" from "market performer."
Added David Wu, analyst at ABN AMRO Chicago Corp.: "Yesterday, I would have said Apple doesn't have a future. Today I say it does."

The new board members bring lots of financial and marketing experience, something shareholders had criticised the previous board for not having, analysts said. The new all-star board also could make it easier for Apple to find a new chief executive.
The Cupertino, Calif., company has been without a CEO and chairman since Amelio was ousted a month ago.
